trans-unit.source: Represents a Windows button control.
A Button can be clicked by using the mouse, ENTER key, or SPACEBAR if the button has focus.

Set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.AcceptButton%2A> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.CancelButton%2A> property of a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form> to allow users to click a button by pressing the ENTER or ESC keys even if the button does not have focus.
This gives the form the behavior of a dialog box.

When you display a form using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.ShowDialog%2A> method, you can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Button.DialogResult%2A> property of a button to specify the return value of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.ShowDialog%2A>.
You can change the button's appearance.
For example, to make it appear flat for a Web look, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ButtonBase.FlatStyle%2A> property to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.FlatStyle?displayProperty=fullName>.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ButtonBase.FlatStyle%2A> property can also be set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.FlatStyle?displayProperty=fullName>, which appears flat until the mouse pointer passes over the button; then the button takes on the standard Windows button appearance.
> [!NOTE] > If the control that has focus accepts and processes the ENTER key press, the Button does not process it.
For example, if a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> or another button has focus, that control processes the ENTER key press instead of the accept button.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Button"></xref> class.
By default the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Button> displays no caption.
To specify the caption text, set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Text%2A> property.
Gets or sets the mode by which the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Button"></xref> automatically resizes itself.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AutoSizeMode"></xref> values.
The default value is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AutoSizeMode"></xref>.
Gets a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.CreateParams"></xref> on the base class when creating a window.

Inheriting classes can override this property to add extra functionality, but must first call the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CreateParams> constructor on the base class to verify that the control continues to work correctly.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.CreateParams"></xref> object on the base class when creating a window.
Gets or sets a value that is returned to the parent form when the button is clicked.

If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult> for this property is set to anything other than `None`, and if the parent form was displayed through the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.ShowDialog%2A> method, clicking the button closes the parent form without your having to hook up any events.
The form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.DialogResult%2A> property is then set to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult> of the button when the button is clicked.
For example, to create a "Yes/No/Cancel" dialog box, simply add three buttons and set their <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult> properties to `Yes`, `No`, and `Cancel`.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult"></xref> values.
The default value is <xref uid="langword_csharp_None" name="None" href=""></xref>.
The value assigned is not one of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DialogResult"></xref> values.
Occurs when the user double-clicks the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Button"></xref> control.

By default, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles?displayProperty=fullName> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles?displayProperty=fullName> style bits are set to `false` for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Button> control, and the DoubleClick event is not raised.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
To be added.
Occurs when the user double-clicks the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Button"></xref> control with the mouse.

By default, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles?displayProperty=fullName> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ControlStyles?displayProperty=fullName> style bits are set to `false` for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Button> control, and the MouseDoubleClick event is not raised.
For more information about handling events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
To be added.
Notifies the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Button"></xref> whether it is the default button so that it can adjust its appearance accordingly.
This method is called by the parent form to notify the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Button> that it should be set as the default button and to allow it to adjust its appearance accordingly.
Typically, a button that is the default button for a form has a thicker border than other buttons on the form.
Calling the NotifyDefault method only draws the button as a default button; it does not change its behavior.
To make the button behave like a default button, it must be assigned to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.AcceptButton%2A> property of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the button is to have the appearance of the default button; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click"></xref> event.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.FontChanged"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The OnFontChanged method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.OnMouseEnter*> event.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.OnMouseLeave*> event.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ButtonBase.OnMouseUp*> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The OnMouseUp method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.TextChanged"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The OnTextChanged method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.
Generates a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click"></xref> event for a button.
This method can be called to raise the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click> event.
Processes a mnemonic character.
When overriding ProcessMnemonic in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's ProcessMnemonic to ensure that basic functionality remains unchanged.
The mnemonic character entered.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the mnemonic was processed; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Returns a <xref:System.String> containing the name of the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Component"></xref>, if any.
This method should not be overridden.

A <xref:System.String> containing the name of the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Component"></xref>, if any, or <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref> if the <xref href="System.ComponentModel.Component"></xref> is unnamed.
Processes Windows messages.
The Windows <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Message"></xref> to process.
